author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Do we expect that as soon as there is a "highly credible date" for withdrawals being enabled (e.g. it's specifically included in a HF) or post-withdrawals-enabled, that there'll be an inflow of Ether to the beaconchain? (there may/will still be a net outflow initially)

author: jgm
content: I suspect not, people who haven't deposited yet will likely wait for withdrawals to be enabled.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Without a set date, there are likely some agents who would not be willing to lock up their Ether (and maintain a node) who otherwise would be.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: So you reckon it's more about the ability to withdraw on demand, than the confidence that one could do so by a particular date?

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: The motivating question is "how will the security vs time curve look like, once withdrawals are enabled".

author: sky.cactus
content: However, I wouldn't recommend anyone rely on a set date (even if one was announced) for making financial decisions.

author: jgm
content: Bear in mind that this should also bring skimming, so lots of genesis validators sitting on 3+ ETH rewards may want to reinvest.  As to if the inputs outweigh the outputs, I doubt anyone really knows due to the number of participants out there.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Are there any withdrawal methods that are lower burden on the beaconchain for skimming than they are for complete exits?

author: jgm
content: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2759#issuecomment-988803796 skimming is healthier for the beacon chain than an exit/re-entry because  validator churn in general isn't good for either the validator or the chain.
